I agree. My point was that the way to test a constructor is to test 
the re=
sults of its behavior. In most cases, it you create an 
instance of the obj=
ect as a fixture in your setUp, you will end up 
testing the constructor in=
 conjuntion with the other tests.

In my earlier programs, I tended to do a=
 lot in my constructors. Now 
as I am focusing more on testability, I am mo=
ving away from that 
approach.

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Andrew McDona=
gh <yahoogroups@...> 
wrote:
>
> whitworthjanet wrote:
> > Since the constr=
uctor takes two parameters, it must do something 
> > with them. I would te=
st that it actually does what it should 
with 
> > them. If it sets member =
variables, were they set, etc.
> >
> >   
> 
> If all they do is that, then=
 I wouldn't bother.  This will be 
tested 
> implicitly within every other =
testcases that use the class.
> 
> Besides, we'd then need someway to check=
 they were set, creating 
> getters, etc., which we probably wouldn't need.=

> 
> If the Responsibility of the Constructor was to validate the  
values=
, by 
> throwing an exception say, then I'd write an explicit test for 
tha=
t.
>
